titlestmt.subtitle: AFC 2018/004

Finding aid encoded by Maya Lerman

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Joseph C. Mele collection of dialect recordings from the University of South Alabama 1975-1980

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of audio recordings of American English dialects from the University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Dialect Tape Center collection created by Professor Joseph C. Mele, a former faculty member, between 1975-1980. The collection includes 346 audiocassettes of 30-minute dialect samples recorded by Mele and other recordists (agents) of individuals in 31 states, as well as 42 recordings of English spoken by non-Americans from 23 different countries. Samples generally consist of two parts: an impromptu monologue and a 44-sentence sequence highlighting each English phoneme.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

title.part: University of South Alabama Dialect Tape Center collection

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by state in the United States, and then by city, county, or region; then alphabetically by non-U.S. countries. The identification codes were assigned by Joseph Mele: the first two letters are state abbrevations; the following two letters are the race/ethnicity of the interviewee (most often black or caucasian) and their gender; and the numbers are the year the interview was conducted, followed by the birth year of the interviewee in parentheses. Original order and numbering were maintained. The original collection guide from the Dialect Tape Center at the University of South Alabama is included in the collection. The collection is organized into the following series and subseries: Series 1. Dialect recordings by geographic area; subseries 1. United States spoken English. Subseries 2. International spoken English.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition
acqinfo.p: University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library; Donation; 2017.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Maya Lerman.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Center for Applied Linguistics collection (AFC 1986/022). The majority of this collection is available online, including recordings made by Joseph Mele for the University of South Alabama: http://www.loc.gov/collections/american-english-dialect-recordings-from-the-center-for-applied-linguistics/?q=mele

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; access to collection materials may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Joseph C. Mele collection of dialect recordings from the University of South Alabama (AFC 2018/004), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph Charles Mele was born in Hammond, Louisiana. He was a graduate of Louisiana State University, where he received a doctorate focusing on communication arts. During his career, he held positions at Louisiana State University, University of Alabama, University of Louisiana-Lafayette, and University of South Alabama where he spent 27 years as professor of speech, speech pathology, audiology, and drama. He died January 12, 2018, in Mobile, Alabama, at the age of 85.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Audio recordings of American English dialects from the University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Dialect Tape Center collection created by Joseph C. Mele, a former faculty member, between 1975-1980. The collection includes 305 audiocassettes of 30-minute dialect samples recorded by Mele and other recordists (agents) of individuals in 31 states, particularly in the South, with more numerous recordings made in Alabama, Tennessee, North Carolina, Virginia, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Missouri. In addition, 41 recordings were made of English spoken by non-Americans from 23 different countries in Asia, Europe, and Australia, as well as in Mexico, Panama, and Nigeria. The birth year of each speaker is documented and ranges from the 1890s to 1950s. Samples generally consist of two parts: an impromtu monologue and a 44-sentence sequence highlighting each English phoneme.

did.unittitle: Series 1. Dialect recordings by geographic area, 1975-1980

scopecontent.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by state, and then by city, county, or region; then alphabetically by non-U.S. countries. The identification codes were assigned by Joseph Mele: the first two letters are state abbrevations; the following two letters are the race/ethnicity of the interviewee (most often black or caucasian) and their gender; and the numbers are the year the interview was conducted, followed by the birth year of the intervieweee in parentheses. Original order and numbering was maintained. Interviews were conducted by Joseph C. Mele, as well as other linguists and recordists, described as agents.
17-page description of the collection from the University of South Alabama Dialect Tape Center, and inventory of tapes, organized alphabetically by state or country.
